The B cell - associated surface molecule <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions to regulate B cell responses .

Cross-linking <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on B cells can lead to homotypic cell adhesion , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production , and , in combination with cytokines , to Ig isotype switching .

text: Tyrosine kinase activity is increased shortly after engagement of this receptor .
Little is known about how the very early events induced by <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cross-linking link to cellular responses .

In this study , we demonstrate that nuclear factor ( NF ) - kappa B and NF-kappa B-like transcription factors are activated after cross-linking <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on resting human tonsillar B cells and on B cell lines .
The activation is rapid and is mediated through a tyrosine kinase - dependent pathway .

The complexes detected in electrophoretic mobility shift assays contain <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RelA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and most likely other components .
By using transient transfection assays , we found that cross-linking <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> supports NF-kappa B - dependent gene expression .

Our results define the NF-kappa B system as an intermediate event in <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling and suggest that the <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pathway can influence the expression of B cell - associated genes with NF-kappa B consensus sites .
